entry.title: How formal should an email be?

link.title: How formal should an email be?

entry.content:
Every year, thousands of students email their professors. And very often â€” not out of malice, but due to inexperience â€” the result is a small communicative disaster.

Between awkward greetings, life-insurance-level phrasing, missing punctuation, and messages like:

Can you tell me where the exam is held?

(Spoiler: Most universities have a dedicated page with this info, updated with near-religious devotion. And if thatâ€™s not enough, thereâ€™s a thing called a student office. Yes, itâ€™s real.)

So, taking inspiration from â€œPoche semplici regole per scrivere una e-mail ad un professoreâ€ (A few simple rules for writing an email to a professor</i) by Professor Davide Dragone, hereâ€™s a guide to writing good emails to faculty. Because between overly formal wording, impersonal verbs, and the panic of not remembering whether the professor told me to use their first nameâ€¦ Iâ€™ve struggled too.

Letâ€™s start with some real examples â€” from ultra-formal toâ€¦ yikes.

Sample emails (from most formal toâ€¦ letâ€™s say â€œless idealâ€)

1. The perfectly formal one

For those aiming to impress either the Academy or the Royal Family

Dear Professor,
My name is C-3PO, and I am enrolled in the XX course.
I am writing to ask whether the handouts for the April 12 lecture will be made available online.
Thank you in advance for your time.
Best regards,
C-3PO

  • Pros: flawless, clear, professional.
  • Cons: couldâ€™ve been written by a highly educated chatbot.
  • Readerâ€™s reaction: approvalâ€¦ mixed with slight existential boredom.

2. The balanced approach

Human, polite, effective â€” my favorite

Good morning Professor,
Iâ€™m C-3PO, a student in the XX course. I was wondering if the April 12 handout will be uploaded to the website soon.
Thanks in advance, and have a great day!
C-3PO

  • Pros: direct, respectful, perfect in most cases.
  • Cons: none. Save it as a draft and reuse forever.
  • Readerâ€™s reaction: smile, fast reply, instant respect.

3. The "yeah, fine" email

Casual but respectful. Aka: normal.

Hi Professor,
I couldnâ€™t find the April 12 handout on the site. Do you know if itâ€™ll be uploaded soon?
Thanks a lot!
C-3PO

  • Pros: simple, practical, human.
  • Cons: better avoided on first contact.
  • Readerâ€™s reaction: fine, but maybe not the best first impression.

4. The "text message from the void"

A kind of teenage S.O.S.

Hi prof u got the slides 4 class 10? need asap

  • Pros: none.
  • Cons: all of them.
  • Readerâ€™s reaction: confusion, pity, slight desire to retire.

5. The "yo prof" vibe

Yes, it exists. No, it shouldnâ€™t.

Yo prof all good? Quick thing: when r u posting slides? Btw the course is ğŸ”¥ see ya in class âœŒï¸

  • Pros: potential TikTok virality.
  • Cons: you just sent this to someone with a PhD.
  • Readerâ€™s reaction: shock, resignation, existential crisis.

If you want to be formalâ€¦

  • Greeting: "Hi Prof" isnâ€™t formal. Itâ€™s the email version of a shrug. Go with "Dear Professor" or "Good morning Professor".
  • Content: Introduce yourself (name, course) and get to the point. Avoid stuff like "I hereby write to inquire regardingâ€¦" â€” this isnâ€™t a Victorian novel.
  • Style: Polite, concise, and with real punctuation. And please, skip the passive-aggressive "Awaiting your reply."
  • Timing: Write whenever you like, but send during working hours. "Schedule send" is your friend. Use it. Youâ€™ll thank yourself.

â€¦but is all this formality always necessary?

Letâ€™s be honest: these rules are useful, but theyâ€™re not the only way to write a good email.

You can be clear, respectful, and kind without sounding like a contract. The right tone depends on the context, your relationship with the professor, the type of university â€” and, letâ€™s be honest, the country.

Thatâ€™s why even something like:

Hi Marco,
Iâ€™m having trouble finding the slides for lecture 10. Do you know if theyâ€™ll be posted soon?
Thanks a lot, talk soon!
C-3PO

For me, thatâ€™s perfectly fine. Not formal, but respectful. And at the end of the day, isnâ€™t that what really matters?

TL;DR?

If you want to write a formal email, do it properly.
But if formality isnâ€™t expected, there are simpler, friendlier, and still respectful alternatives.

Because, in the end, politeness beats formalism. Always.
